questions.question: The tropical transitional climatic zone is:
options: a. approximately $20^{\circ}-30^{\circ}$ of latitude and provides very dry desert conditions throughout the year
b. approximately $10^{\circ}-20^{\circ}$ of latitude and provides dry trade wind conditions in winter and a wet summer season
c. approximately $10^{\circ}-20^{\circ}$ of latitude and provides a wet winter season and a dry hot summer
d. approximately $10^{\circ}-30^{\circ}$ of latitude and has a period of long rains in spring and autumn, but is never dry

questions.question: The temperate transitional climatic zone is:
options: a. approximately $20^{\circ}-35^{\circ}$ of latitude and covers the high pressure desert regions of the world
b. approximately $35^{\circ}-40^{\circ}$ of latitude and is under the influence of polar front depressions throughout the year
c. approximately 35°-40° of latitude and provides a warm dry summer with a cool wet winter
d. approximately $35^{\circ}-40^{\circ}$ of latitude and provides a wet summer season and a dry cold winter

questions.question: Northern Hemisphere summers tend to be:
options: a. warmer than the Southern Hemisphere and winters are warmer too
b. colder than the Southern Hemisphere due to the smaller amount of solar radiation
c. colder than the Southern Hemisphere because of the large land masses
d. warmer than the Southern Hemisphere and the winters are colder

questions.question: The effect of mountain barriers on temperature is exemplified by the following:
options: a. European temperatures are low in winter because there is no barrier to prevent cold Atlantic air crossing the area
b. the Rocky mountains of North America prevent cold Pacific air reaching inland, so summer temperatures to the east of the mountains are high
c. the Himalayas prevent warm dry air from Russia reaching India and Pakistan
d. the Ural mountains of West Russia prevent most of the cold Siberian air reaching Europe in summer

questions.question: The tropopause is:
options: a. more or less constant for any latitude
b. is a boundary layer between the troposphere and the stratosphere
c. normally the upper limit of weather
d. the upper limit for jet streams and mountain waves

questions.question: Statistical pressure values tend to be:
options: a. on average parallel to the lines of latitude
b. on average parallel to the lines of latitude in the Southern Hemisphere and much more variable in the Northern Hemisphere
c. much lower in winter in the Northern Hemisphere than in the Southern Hemisphere
d. higher over the oceans in winter

questions.question: The heat equator is:
options: a. another name for the geographic equator
b. coincident with the equatorial trough and ITCZ
c. a line over the land joining places where the summer temperatures are highest
d. a line over the land joining places where the winter temperatures are highest

questions.question: The average temperature around the equatorial regions:
options: a. is always above $+40^{\circ}C$
b. is higher over the sea areas
c. varies on average from winter to summer by only some $5^{\circ}C$
d. has a very high range of temperatures throughout the year

questions.question: Trade winds:
options: a. blow towards the subtropical anticyclones
b. are caused by lifting over the heat equator and the subsequent air movements from the subtropical anticyclones
c. only blow in the winter months
d. blow from the equatorial low pressure systems throughout the year

questions.question: Trade winds in the Southern Hemisphere are:
options: a. southeasterly
b. southeast at first becoming southwest
c. in opposition to the monsoons
d. usually from the northeast

questions.question: The Hadley cell is the name given to:
options: a. the CU cells which continue to form a CB
b. an initial bubble of air which is lifted by convection
c. the centre portion of a jet stream
d. a cell formed by lifted air over the heat equator descending to the subtropical highs

questions.question: The large change in the direction of trade winds is caused by:
options: a. local pressure differences
b. an excess of air at height in association with the Hadley cells
c. the change in geostrophic force when crossing the geographic equator
d. the cyclostrophic force in the equatorial regions

questions.question: Monsoons are seasonal winds which:
options: a. develop due to the high pressure over continents in winter and the subsequent low pressure which develops over the same areas in summer
b. are never in combination with trade winds
c. are from the southeasterly direction over the Indian sub continent in summer
d. blow only in the southeast Asia region

questions.question: The outflow from the Siberian High:
options: a. is northwesterly over Japan, northerly and northeasterly over China and northerly over the whole of India
b. is the source of Polar Maritime air
c. is northwesterly over Japan, northeasterly over southeast Asia and easterly over Europe
d. is evident throughout the year

questions.question: The upper winds tend to be westerly outside the tropics because:
options: a. the rotation of the earth is west to east
b. the thermal winds are westerly on average
c. surface winds are nearly always westerly
d. jet streams are usually westerly

questions.question: Jet stream main locations are:
options: a. in the warm air some 400 NM ahead of a warm or cold front and near the subtropical highs
b. in the warm air some 400 NM ahead of a warm front and some 200 NM behind a cold front and near the subtropical highs
c. only in association with the polar front
d. in association with the polar front and with mountain waves

questions.question: Jet streams:
options: a. only occur in the troposphere
b. have a speed in excess of 80 kt
c. are located above the tropopause
d. are caused by a large difference in mean temperature in the horizontal

questions.question: Near the Equator upper winds tend to be:
options: a. easterly
b. westerly
c. at speeds greater than 60 kt
d. calm

questions.question: The polar front is:
options: a. the boundary surface between polar continental and tropical continental air
b. near the poles
c. only apparent over the Atlantic ocean
d. the region where warm sector depressions develop

questions.question: The ITCZ is:
options: a. the region between the two trade wind systems centred on the heat equator
b. the boundary region between the two monsoons
c. the boundary between polar air and equatorial air
d. a region of calm winds and layer type clouds with much haze

questions.question: Tropical revolving storms:
options: a. are a summer weather feature
b. are easily predictable
c. can be very active well inland
d. can travel at speeds of 100 kt

questions.question: The areas of greatest rainfall are:
options: a. those where there is much polar front depression activity
b. in the equatorial regions
c. in the polar regions
d. in central North America in summer due to the large convective cloud formations

questions.question: Thunderstorms most frequently occur:
options: a. in association with the ITCZ over central Africa
b. over the east Indies area (Java) due to the intense surface heating
c. in regions affected by cold fronts
d. in association with tropical revolving storms

questions.question: Dust storms and haze are most common:
options: a. in association with the subtropical anticyclones over land
b. with the Haboobs in winter
c. in unstable air with low pressure
d. in temperate latitudes

questions.question: The most notorious advection fogs occur:
options: a. over southwest UK
b. over the sea in the region of Newfoundland and the Kamchatka peninsula
c. over Europe with high pressure to the north
d. over central North America in autumn and winter

questions.question: The cloud to be expected along the front at A3 in Appendix A is:
options: a. CU CB
b. ST SC
c. ST NS
d. AS NS

questions.question: The cloud to be expected at B2 between the fronts in Appendix A is:
options: a. AS
b. ST SC
c. NS
d. NIL

questions.question: The cloud to be expected at C2 along the front in Appendix A is:
options: a. CU CB
b. AS NS
c. ST SC
d. AC

questions.question: The cloud to be expected along the front at A2 in Appendix A is:
options: a. CI
b. AS NS
c. ST
d. CU

questions.question: The average surface level winds at A3, B3 and C3 in Appendix A are respectively:
options: a. easterly, westerly, southwesterly
b. westerly, westerly, southwesterly
c. southwesterly, westerly, northwesterly
d. southwesterly, westerly, northerly

questions.question: The average upper winds at A1, B1 and C1 in Appendix A are respectively:
options: a. easterly, westerly, northwesterly
b. northwesterly, westerly, southwesterly
c. southwesterly, westerly, northwesterly
d. southwesterly, westerly, northerly

questions.question: The names of the air masses indicated A, B, C and D at Appendix B are respectively:
options: a. Polar Maritime, Polar Continental, Tropical Maritime, Tropical Continental
b. Returning Polar Maritime, Arctic, Tropical Continental, Tropical Maritime
c. Polar Maritime, Arctic, Tropical Continental, Tropical Maritime
d. Polar Maritime, Arctic, Polar Continental, Tropical Maritime

questions.question: The names of the air masses indicated E, F, G and H at Appendix B are respectively:
options: a. Tropical Maritime, Polar Continental, Tropical Continental, Arctic
b. Polar Continental, Tropical Maritime, Tropical Continental, Arctic
c. Polar Continental, Tropical Continental, Tropical Maritime, Arctic
d. Tropical Maritime, Polar Maritime, Tropical Continental, Polar Maritime

questions.question:
REFER TO THE ABOVE DIAGRAM FOR QUESTIONS 34-39.
In area L the main wet seasons will be:
options: a. at the equinoxes
b. in January/February
c. in July/August
d. in November/December

questions.question: In area M in winter there will be:
options: a. equatorial rains
b. extensive low cloud
c. the Doldrums
d. dry trade wind conditions

questions.question: In area N there will be:
options: a. extensive winter rains
b. anticyclonic desert areas
c. dry summers and wet winters
d. polar front weather

questions.question: In area O the climate will include:
options: a. the trade winds
b. dry warm summers and a wet winter season
c. steppe type with grassy plains
d. a wet summer and dry cold winters

questions.question: In area P the main weather factor will be:
options: a. polar front depressions
b. depressions in winter, anticyclones in summer
c. monsoon weather
d. extensive low cloud throughout the year

questions.question: In area Q the climate will include:
options: a. polar front depressions
b. cold anticyclonic weather
c. temperatures above zero for 3 months of the year
d. good visibility throughout the year
